title: Black Panther's Lupita Nyong'o defends Marvel over Martin Scorsese comments
text:
Lupita starred in last year’s Black Panther. (Picture: Getty Images)

Lupita Nyong’o has answered critics of Marvel movies, pointing out Black Panther was both ‘popular’ and ‘meaningful’.

She makes a good point!

The Oscar-winner was responding to a long line of celebrated directors who have publicly trashed superhero movies like Avengers: Endgame.

Among them are Francis Ford Coppola, director of Apocalypse Now and the Godfather trilogy, who this week called such films ‘despicable.’

Goodfellas director Martin Scorsese has meanwhile recently called the movies ‘not cinema’ while I, Daniel Blake director Ken Loach said they’re ‘commodities like hamburgers.’

Lupita addressed the criticism at yesterday’s BAFTA Britannia Awards in Los Angeles.

Lupita has also starred in this year’s horror hit Us, directed by Jordan Peele. (Picture: Getty Images)

She told PA: ‘I believe that it’s possible to be both a popular film and a meaningful film and I think Black Panther showed that.’

Totally fair comment!

Lupita of course won the 2013 Best Supporting Actress Oscar for 12 Years a Slave.

She has also starred in hits like this year’s horror flick Us and zombie comedy Little Monsters.

The actress recently touched on Black Panther while discussing whether the casting experience for black actors has changed as a result of the film’s success.

Lupita’s next film will be Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker, out next month. (Picture: Getty Images)

‘I think time will tell whether this has been that pivotal shift. It definitely feels that way,’ she said.

The 36-year-old made the comment while discussing colourism, explaining she ‘once auditioned for something on TV and I was told I was too dark to be on television,’ adding that ‘I definitely grew up feeling uncomfortable with my skin colour because I felt like the world around me awarded lighter skin.’

Calling colourism ‘the daughter of racism’, she continued: ‘We still ascribe to these notions of Eurocentric standards of beauty, that then affect how we see ourselves among ourselves.’

She added: ‘Race is a very social construct, one that I didn’t have to ascribe to on a daily basis growing up. As much as I was experiencing colourism in Kenya, I wasn’t aware that I belonged to a race called black.’
